questions.question: What is the primary goal of data modeling?
options: To design the user interface
To organize and document a system's data
To write program code
To test system performance
questions.correctAnswerText: To organize and document a system's data

questions.question: What is an 'entity' in data modeling?
options: A single piece of data
A relationship between tables
A class of persons, places, objects, events, or concepts about which data is stored
A type of database software
questions.correctAnswerText: A class of persons, places, objects, events, or concepts about which data is stored

questions.question: What is an 'attribute' in data modeling?
options: A descriptive property or characteristic of an entity
A connection between two entities
A unique identifier for a database
A type of data relationship
questions.correctAnswerText: A descriptive property or characteristic of an entity

questions.question: What is a 'primary key'?
options: An optional attribute
A foreign key from another table
A candidate key used to uniquely identify a single entity instance
A duplicate attribute in two entities
questions.correctAnswerText: A candidate key used to uniquely identify a single entity instance

questions.question: What does 'cardinality' describe in a relationship?
options: The name of the relationship
The minimum and maximum number of occurrences of one entity related to another
The data type of an attribute
The degree of normalization
questions.correctAnswerText: The minimum and maximum number of occurrences of one entity related to another

questions.question: What is a 'foreign key'?
options: A key that is never used
A primary key of one entity that is duplicated in another entity to identify a relationship
A temporary key during data entry
A key used only in reports
questions.correctAnswerText: A primary key of one entity that is duplicated in another entity to identify a relationship

questions.question: What is a 'recursive relationship'?
options: A relationship between three entities
A relationship between instances of the same entity
A relationship that is always one-to-one
A relationship that cannot be modeled
questions.correctAnswerText: A relationship between instances of the same entity

questions.question: What is an 'associative entity'?
options: An entity with no attributes
An entity that inherits its primary key from more than one parent entity
An entity that cannot have relationships
An entity used only in documentation
questions.correctAnswerText: An entity that inherits its primary key from more than one parent entity

questions.question: What is a 'nonspecific relationship'?
options: A one-to-one relationship
A relationship between a parent and child
A many-to-many relationship
A relationship with no cardinality

questions.question: What is 'normalization' in data modeling?
options: Adding more attributes to an entity
Deleting all foreign keys
A technique to organize data into nonredundant, stable, and flexible groups
A method to increase data duplication
questions.correctAnswerText: A technique to organize data into nonredundant, stable, and flexible groups

questions.question: What is 'first normal form (1NF)'?
options: An entity with no primary key
An entity whose attributes have no more than one value per instance
An entity with only one attribute
An entity in a many-to-many relationship
questions.correctAnswerText: An entity whose attributes have no more than one value per instance

questions.question: What is a 'compound attribute'?
options: An attribute with no value
An attribute that consists of other attributes
An attribute that is a primary key
An attribute used only in reports
questions.correctAnswerText: An attribute that consists of other attributes

questions.question: What is a 'domain' in data modeling?
options: The name of the database
The relationship between two entities
The number of instances in an entity
The set of legitimate values an attribute can take
questions.correctAnswerText: The set of legitimate values an attribute can take

questions.question: What is a 'weak entity'?
options: An entity with no attributes
An entity whose primary key includes the primary key of another entity
An entity that is not used in the system
An entity with only one instance
questions.correctAnswerText: An entity whose primary key includes the primary key of another entity

questions.question: What does 'degree' refer to in a relationship?
options: The importance of the relationship
The number of attributes in an entity
The number of entities that participate in the relationship
The level of normalization
questions.correctAnswerText: The number of entities that participate in the relationship
